newsitem.title: UK: Charles poses again, Diana media frenzy unabated.
newsitem.headline: Charles poses again, Diana media frenzy unabated.

text.p: Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, interrupted his summer break in Scotland for the second time on Saturday to pose with his two sons for photographers.

Royal aides denied suggestions that the rare photo-call on the royal family's vast private Balmoral estate in rural Scotland was a bid to deflect attention from the media fenzy over Princess Diana's romance with millionaire Egyptian playboy Dodi Al Fayed.

The shots of Charles, dressed in a green kilt, beside a waterfall with princes William and Harry, seemed hardly likely to grab world newspaper headlines dominated by the affair of Diana, Dodi and spurned other woman Kelly Fisher.
Diana flew out to Greece with a woman friend on her third Mediterranean holiday in two months, leaving behind a breach of contract suit brought against the new man in her life by U.S. model Kelly.
Kelly claims she was Al Fayed's fiancee until pictures of him kissing Diana appeared in newspapes around the world.

Dodi, son of Harrods boss Mohammed Al Fayed, has denied her claims but the saga looked certain to run with Britain's best-selling Sunday newspaper, the News Of The World, promising that Fisher would be telling the tabloid her side of the story.

Charles, who was divorced from Diana a year ago, usually guards his privacy jealously during his annual holiday at Balmoral and seeks to protect their sons from the more unsavoury publicity surrounding the marriage breakup.
Royal aides said that by volunteering to pose for photogaphers there, Charles and the boys would be left in peace for the rest of their break.

"It was an experiment. I am not saying it's setting a precedent. It has worked. We want to work with the media, we will come halfway if you leave them alone," the prince's press spokeswoman Sandy Henney told reporters.

Henney denied the two photo-calls were part of a "charm offensive" by the prince, who faces an uphill task as the next king after opinion polls showed popularity for the monarchy slumping to below 50 percent for the first time.
Henney said Charles and his sons were grateful for being left alone since first posing for photographers on Tuesday.
"It's meant a lot to them. They have been able to go places and do things, they have not been previously able to do," she said.
British newspapers remained obsessed with Diana and Dodi on Saturday.
The Sun splashed a front-page picture of Al Fayed arm in arm with Fisher and inside carried the results of a telephone poll by its readers -- they voted five to one for "Di to dump Dodi."
Readers who sent in humorous limericks -- dubbed "Di and Dodi odes" -- were given 30 pound prizes for the best ones.
Other tabloids also rounded on Al Fayed. "You're a Dodi rotten cheat," declared the Daily Mirror.
